q1.value: Effect of interest on assigning labels under referential ambiguity

q2.value: Lena Ackermann, Claudia Wasmuth, Elizabeth Johnson, Nivedita Mani

q3.value: When learning new words, young children are constantly faced with referential ambiguity. It has been shown that children make use of a number of cues and techniques to resolve this ambiguity. At the same time, children have been shown to learn words better from categories they are more interested in. In this study, we examine whether children aged 30 to 36 months use their individual interests to resolve referential ambiguity in the absence of other cues.

q4.value: If children use category interest to resolve referential ambiguity, they will show increased target looking to a novel object from a high-interest category. If children use object interest to resolve referential ambiguity, they will show increased target looking to a high-interest object.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We use a within-subject design with four factors (pupillary arousal to familiar objects, pupillary arousal to novel objects, looking time at novel and familiar objects, parental ratings of children’s interest and familiarity with objects from different categories). 
The experiment is divided into three phases: an object presentation phase, a learning phase, and a test phase. In the object presentation phase, children see a total of 20 objects: 16 familiar objects (four from each of the four categories) and one novel object from each category. During this phase, the change in pupil dilation from a scrambled baseline image of the same object to an unscrambled image of the object is recorded (preprocessing steps for the pupillary data will be undertaken as described in Ackermann, Hepach, & Mani, 2019). In the learning phase, children see two of novel objects side-by-side while they hear a novel label 10 times, without any clues as to which of the objects is being referred to by the novel label. Here, their looking times at the two objects are measured. In the test phase, children see the two novel objects side-by-side again and hear either the previously learnt label or a novel label (see below for details). The order of the objects in the presentation phase and the assignment of labels to novel object pairs in counterbalanced across lists. 
In addition, parents fill out a questionnaire about their child’s interest in and familiarity with the categories used in the study.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The data has been collected using an eyetracker, but has not yet been exported at the time of the preregistration. Thus, it has not yet been accessed by any researchers.

question.value: Children aged between 30;0 and 36;31 months of age were recruited through the institute’s participant database. All children were monolingual German learners, not born more than 6 weeks prematurely and reported to have normal vision and hearing. Children received a book in return for their participation in the study. Data collection started in November 2019 and finished in March 2020.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 40 children. 10 additional children were recruited and tested to account for possible drop-outs.

question.value: Our outcome variable is baseline-corrected proportion of target looking (PTL, defined as looks to the target divided by overall looks to the target and distractor). Each test trial is split into a prenaming phase (before hearing the label) and a postnaming phase (starting with the onset of the label). Baseline-corrected PTL is defined as postnaming PTL corrected for prenaming PTL. A baseline-corrected PTL of 0 indicates no increase in fixation to the target from the pre-naming to the post-naming phase, while PTL > 0 indicates an increase in fixations to the target relative to the distractor from the pre- to the post-naming and is commonly interpreted as successful recognition.

We will use linear mixed-effect models (LMMs) to analyze the effect of each of the four interest measures on word recognition (as indexed by PTL). For each predictor, we will separately fit a model with the following structure:

Baseline-corrected PTL ~ predictor + (1|id) + (1|category) + (1|id:category)

The random effect structure will be reduced in case of convergence issues.

q24.value:
In the main confirmatory analysis, we look at the four interest measures separately. In an additional exploratory analysis, we want to look at the contribution of each predictor using a full model that includes all four measures. By using the drop1-function (which compares a model with a certain predictor to a model without this predictor), we can examine the individual contribution of each measure. The assignments of targets might differ depending on the interest measure, so we will fit two different models: The first model will use the target assignments based on the category interest pupil measure, the second model will use the target assignments based on the parental ratings. A previous study (Ackermann, Hepach, & Mani, 2019) showed that while the two measures don’t correlate with each other, they modulate recognition in a strikingly similar way.

In another analysis, we want to compare inter- and intra-category variability in pupil dilation. In a previous study, category interest was determined by averaging across all category members, not accounting for possible outliers. We want to examine whether children show similar increases in pupil dilation for different members of the same category.

We also collected production data from the children in an offline task after the eyetracking study. Children were shown pictures of the novel objects and asked to name them. Some children provided labels that go with similar-looking objects (such as calling the easel a ladder or calling the segway a scooter). However, we cannot determine whether children actually categorized the novel objects as those known objects (meaning that they would reject a novel label for these objects based on the principle of mutual exclusivity) or whether they felt forced to provide a label to comply with instructions and went for “the next best thing”. We will therefore run all analyses again excluding trials with objects for which children provided a label that was not the one introduced during the experiment.

q2.value: Lily Syfers, David Rast III, James Peabody

q3.value: Research on intergroup sensitivity (e.g. Hornsey & Imani, 2004) demonstrates that in-group members are more resistant to out-group critics than in-group critics, because out-group critics are perceived as undermining the in-group. Similarly, an out-group critic who is perceived as undermining an in-group leader may also be perceived as undermining the in-group. We model how support for an in-group leader is positively impacted by out-group criticism of the leader.

q4.value: Perceived criticism of an in-group leader by an out-group predicts perceived criticism of the self, which strengthens collective identification with a leader and predicts support for the leader.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Cross - sectional survey with 7 observed variables, all adapted from scales used in previous research. See attachment for full survey flow and measure items. 

Out-group criticism: 3 items adapted from Hooley & Teasdale, (1989)
Collective identification with leader: 
Leader prototypicality: 4 items adapted from van Knippenberg & van Knippenberg (2005) 
Legitimacy of criticism: 3 items adapted from Hooley & Teasdale, (1989)
Perceived collective criticism: 3 items adapted from Hornsey & Imani (2004) and Hooley & Teasdale, (1989)
Anger: 4 items adapted from Hornsey & Imani (2004)
Collective anger: 4 items adapted from Hornsey & Imani (2004)
Leader support: 9 items adapted from Rast, Gaffney, Hogg and Crisp (2012)

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: At the time of registration, data collection through Mturk has only very recently begun (within 24 hours). Because we have run a power analysis, we know our target sample size and will not be accessing or analyzing data until data are collected in full.

question.value: Participants are recruited through Mturk, and will be paid $.45 upon completion of the survey. Restriction criteria set on Mturk is that participants must be Republican American citizens age 18 or older.

q14.value:
We used Preacher's r code generator to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .8 power to detect a good fit of .04 (RMSEA) at the standard .05 alpha level. 

Preacher, K. J., & Coffman, D. L. (2006, May). Computing power and minimum sample size for RMSEA [Computer software]. Available from http://quantpsy.org/.

q15.value: On Mturk we have placed a cap on the number of participants who can take the study. After we reach our target sample size, no additional participants can take the study.

question.value: We are not manipulating any variables.

Exogenous variable: Out-group criticism: 3 items adapted from Hooley & Teasdale (1989)

Endogenous variables:
Collective identification with leader: 8 items adapted from Hohman & Hogg (2015b) 
Leader prototypicality: 4 items adapted from van Knippenberg & van Knippenberg (2005) 
Legitimacy of criticism: 3 items adapted from Hooley & Teasdale, (1989)
Perceived collective criticism: 3 items adapted from Hornsey & Imani (2004); and Hooley & Teasdale, (1989)
Anger: 4 items adapted from van Zomeren et al (2004) 
Collective anger: 4 items adapted from van Zomeren et al (2004) 

Outcome: Leader support: 9 items adapted from Rast, Gaffney, Hogg and Crisp (2012)
Items for each measure will be combined by row means for each participant to create a composite score for the measure.
Structural equation model using simulated data for model fit evaluation. Attachment is R script for simulated data.

q21.value: We will use a RMSEA value of .08 as a cut off for an acceptable model fit.

q22.value: We will examine outliers (3 standard deviations from the mean). Outliers will be dropped if any significant association is made by the outliers.

q23.value: Participants with missing data (i.e. those who did not fully complete the study and dropped out early) will be removed.

q24.value: We will test the model with people who had or had not voted for the in-group leader in a previous election, and with those who intend to or do not intend to vote for the in-group leader in the upcoming election.

question.value:
We use a within-subject design with four factors (pupillary arousal to familiar objects, pupillary arousal to novel objects, looking time at novel and familiar objects, parental ratings of children’s interest and familiarity with objects from different categories). 
The experiment is divided into three phases: an object presentation phase, a learning phase, and a test phase. In the object presentation phase, children see a total of 20 objects: 16 familiar objects (four from each of the four categories) and one novel object from each category. During this phase, the change in pupil dilation from a scrambled baseline image of the same object to an unscrambled image of the object is recorded (preprocessing steps for the pupillary data will be undertaken as described in Ackermann, Hepach, & Mani, 2019). In the learning phase, children see two of novel objects side-by-side while they hear a novel label 10 times, without any clues as to which of the objects is being referred to by the novel label. Here, their looking times at the two objects are measured. In the test phase, children see the two novel objects side-by-side again and hear either the previously learnt label or a novel label (see below for details). The order of the objects in the presentation phase and the assignment of labels to novel object pairs in counterbalanced across lists. 
In addition, parents fill out a questionnaire about their child’s interest in and familiarity with the categories used in the study.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The data has been collected using an eyetracker, but has not yet been exported at the time of the preregistration. Thus, it has not yet been accessed by any researchers.

question.value: Children aged between 30;0 and 36;31 months of age were recruited through the institute’s participant database. All children were monolingual German learners, not born more than 6 weeks prematurely and reported to have normal vision and hearing. Children received a book in return for their participation in the study. Data collection started in November 2019 and finished in March 2020.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 40 children. 10 additional children were recruited and tested to account for possible drop-outs.

question.value: Our outcome variable is baseline-corrected proportion of target looking (PTL, defined as looks to the target divided by overall looks to the target and distractor). Each test trial is split into a prenaming phase (before hearing the label) and a postnaming phase (starting with the onset of the label). Baseline-corrected PTL is defined as postnaming PTL corrected for prenaming PTL. A baseline-corrected PTL of 0 indicates no increase in fixation to the target from the pre-naming to the post-naming phase, while PTL > 0 indicates an increase in fixations to the target relative to the distractor from the pre- to the post-naming and is commonly interpreted as successful recognition.

We will use linear mixed-effect models (LMMs) to analyze the effect of each of the four interest measures on word recognition (as indexed by PTL). For each predictor, we will separately fit a model with the following structure:

Baseline-corrected PTL ~ predictor + (1|id) + (1|category) + (1|id:category)

The random effect structure will be reduced in case of convergence issues.

q24.value:
In the main confirmatory analysis, we look at the four interest measures separately. In an additional exploratory analysis, we want to look at the contribution of each predictor using a full model that includes all four measures. By using the drop1-function (which compares a model with a certain predictor to a model without this predictor), we can examine the individual contribution of each measure. The assignments of targets might differ depending on the interest measure, so we will fit two different models: The first model will use the target assignments based on the category interest pupil measure, the second model will use the target assignments based on the parental ratings. A previous study (Ackermann, Hepach, & Mani, 2019) showed that while the two measures don’t correlate with each other, they modulate recognition in a strikingly similar way.

In another analysis, we want to compare inter- and intra-category variability in pupil dilation. In a previous study, category interest was determined by averaging across all category members, not accounting for possible outliers. We want to examine whether children show similar increases in pupil dilation for different members of the same category.

We also collected production data from the children in an offline task after the eyetracking study. Children were shown pictures of the novel objects and asked to name them. Some children provided labels that go with similar-looking objects (such as calling the easel a ladder or calling the segway a scooter). However, we cannot determine whether children actually categorized the novel objects as those known objects (meaning that they would reject a novel label for these objects based on the principle of mutual exclusivity) or whether they felt forced to provide a label to comply with instructions and went for “the next best thing”. We will therefore run all analyses again excluding trials with objects for which children provided a label that was not the one introduced during the experiment.

q1.value: Effect of interest on assigning labels under referential ambiguity

q2.value: Lena Ackermann, Claudia Wasmuth, Elizabeth Johnson, Nivedita Mani

q3.value: When learning new words, young children are constantly faced with referential ambiguity. It has been shown that children make use of a number of cues and techniques to resolve this ambiguity. At the same time, children have been shown to learn words better from categories they are more interested in. In this study, we examine whether children aged 30 to 36 months use their individual interests to resolve referential ambiguity in the absence of other cues.

q4.value: If children use category interest to resolve referential ambiguity, they will show increased target looking to a novel object from a high-interest category. If children use object interest to resolve referential ambiguity, they will show increased target looking to a high-interest object.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We use a within-subject design with four factors (pupillary arousal to familiar objects, pupillary arousal to novel objects, looking time at novel and familiar objects, parental ratings of children’s interest and familiarity with objects from different categories). 
The experiment is divided into three phases: an object presentation phase, a learning phase, and a test phase. In the object presentation phase, children see a total of 20 objects: 16 familiar objects (four from each of the four categories) and one novel object from each category. During this phase, the change in pupil dilation from a scrambled baseline image of the same object to an unscrambled image of the object is recorded (preprocessing steps for the pupillary data will be undertaken as described in Ackermann, Hepach, & Mani, 2019). In the learning phase, children see two of novel objects side-by-side while they hear a novel label 10 times, without any clues as to which of the objects is being referred to by the novel label. Here, their looking times at the two objects are measured. In the test phase, children see the two novel objects side-by-side again and hear either the previously learnt label or a novel label (see below for details). The order of the objects in the presentation phase and the assignment of labels to novel object pairs in counterbalanced across lists. 
In addition, parents fill out a questionnaire about their child’s interest in and familiarity with the categories used in the study.

question.value: Our outcome variable is baseline-corrected proportion of target looking (PTL, defined as looks to the target divided by overall looks to the target and distractor). We will use linear mixed-effect models (LMMs) to analyze the effect of each of the four interest measures on word recognition (as indexed by PTL). For each predictor, we will separately fit a model with the following structure:

Baseline-corrected PTL ~ predictor + (1|id) + (1|category) + (1|id:category)

The random effect structure will be reduced in case of convergence issues.

q24.value:
In the main confirmatory analysis, we look at the four interest measures separately. In an additional exploratory analysis, we want to look at the contribution of each predictor using a full model that includes all four measures. By using the drop1-function (which compares a model with a certain predictor to a model without this predictor), we can examine the individual contribution of each measure. The assignments of targets might differ depending on the interest measure, so we will fit two different models: The first model will use the target assignments based on the category interest pupil measure, the second model will use the target assignments based on the parental ratings. A previous study (Ackermann, Hepach, & Mani, 2019) showed that while the two measures don’t correlate with each other, they modulate recognition in a strikingly similar way.

In another analysis, we want to compare inter- and intra-category variability in pupil dilation. In a previous study, category interest was determined by averaging across all category members, not accounting for possible outliers. We want to examine whether children show similar increases in pupil dilation for different members of the same category.

We also collected production data from the children in an offline task after the eyetracking study. Children were shown pictures of the novel objects and asked to name them. Some children provided labels that go with similar-looking objects (such as calling the easel a ladder or calling the segway a scooter). However, we cannot determine whether children actually categorized the novel objects as those known objects (meaning that they would reject a novel label for these objects based on the principle of mutual exclusivity) or whether they felt forced to provide a label to comply with instructions and went for “the next best thing”. We will therefore run all analyses again excluding trials with objects for which children provided a label that was not the one introduced during the experiment.

attributes.title: Cardioprotective effect of electro-acupuncture for myocardial injury in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention: study protocol for a meta-analysis and systematic review

q1.value: Clinical efficacy and safety of Spironolactone in patients with resistant hypertension: A systematic review and meta-analysis

q3.value:
Background
We conducted the meta-analysis to summarize all available evidence from randomized controlled trial (RCT) studies regarding the clinical efficacy and safety of spironolactone in patients with resistant hypertension, and provided a quantitative assessment.
Methods
A systematic search of PubMed, Web of Science, Cochrane Library, Embase, China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI) until December 8, 2019, was performed. Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) meeting inclusion criteria were included to assess the effect of additional spironolactone on office blood pressure (BP), 24h ambulatory BP or adverse events in RH patients.
Results
Involving 12 trials enroll a total of 1655 patients in this meta-analysis. In comparison with placebo group, spironolactone reduced significantly office BP( office SBP, WMD = -20.14, 95% CI = -31.17 to -9.12, P < 0.001; office DBP WMD = -5.73, 95% CI = -8.13 to -3.33, P < 0.001) and 24h ambulatory ( ASBP, WMD = -10.31, 95% CI = -12.86 to -7.76, P < 0.001; ADSP, WMD = -3.94, 95% CI = -5.50 to -2.37, P < 0.001). Compared with alternative drugs, spironolactone treatment in RH patients significantly decreased 24h ambulatory BP (ASBP, WMD = -6.98, 95% CI = -12.66 to -1.30, P < 0.05; ADSP, WMD = -3.03, 95% CI = -5.21 to -0.85, P < 0.001). 
Conclusion 
This meta-analysis fully evaluated the antihypertensive effect of spironolactone compared with placebo, alternative drugs, RND and blank groups. And spironolactone can result in a substantial BP reduction in patients with RH at 3-month time.

q4.value: addition of spironolactone to triple-drug therapy was the most eﬀective add-on drug for patients with resistant hypertension

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: According to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA)  guidelines, the meta-analysis was performed to elaborate the effect of Spironolactone on resistant hypertension.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: Relevant data was collected independently by two reviewers and the third reviewer was responsible for resolving discrepancies through discussion. Standardized predefined form was used include 4 parts: (1) basic information: title, the first author, year of publication, and corresponding address; (2) study characteristics: type of interferences and control, daily dosage of intervention, study design, inclusion and exclusion criteria, RH definition; (3) the characteristics of participants: sample size, gender distribution, mean age and race; (4) results of the study: outcome measures of blood pressure and heart rate. When there were missing, errors or ambiguous information in included studies, we will contact original authors of the study. If the author failed to answer the questions, the insufficient information would be neglected or the study would be excluded. Different opinions between reviewers were resolved by communicated with others reviewers.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 10 studies

question.value: All the statistical analyses were performed using Cochrane Program Review Manager Version 5.3 (Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK). We used I2 test and chi-square test to evaluate the heterogeneity of included RCTs, which was to estimate the discrepancy across studies ( When I2 values <50% and P>0.10, there was not obvious heterogeneity). Random effect model was utilized when heterogeneity was obvious, otherwise fixed-effect model was used. The risk ratio (RR) and the mean difference (MD) were used to represent binary variable and Continuous variables respectively, with a 95% confidence interval (CI). Constructing a Funnel Graph was used to detect publication bias.

attributes.title: On the improvement of the subjective SES scale

q1.value: On the improvement of the MacArthur Subjective Socio-economic Status Scale

q2.value: Céline Darnon, Marie Crouzevialle, Benoit Dompnier, Ulrich von Hecker

q3.value:
The goal of the present research is to examine the predictive validity of two subjective SES scales. The original scale (the MacArthur Subjective Socio-economic Status Scale, Adler, Epel, Castellazzo, & Ickovics, 2000) has 10 rungs, ranging from 1 (low subjective SES) to 10 (high subjective SES). We believe an important limitation of this SES scale is that the highest numbers (10) represent the highest ranked individuals in the hierarchy and the lowest numbers (1) represent the lowest ranked individuals in the hierarchy. This may introduce some confusion. Indeed, individuals generally perceive the society as being like a pyramid (Niehues, 2014) implying that small numbers may be expected to be located at the top of a vertical display, not at the bottom. In addition, participants usually respond more accurately to questions when the modalities of answers are presented in a linear ranked order (e.g., 1 10) rather than in a different order in which the primacy within the order follows the trained reading/writing direction (von Hecker, Klauer, Wolf, Fazilat-Pour, 2016). 
For these reasons, we believe a reversed scale (1 at the top, 10 at the bottom) would be better understood by the participants than the original scale (1 at the bottom, 10 at the top), which should increase its predictive validity.

q4.value: Hypothesis: The reversed scale ("1 at the top") should be more strongly related to other indicators of social status (level of education, income) than the original scale ("1 at the bottom").

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: This is an online study. Participants will be randomly assigned to one or the other of the experimental condition.

question.value:
Depending on the condition, participants will be presented either the original subjective SES scale (the higher the SES, the higher the numbers) or the reversed one (the higher the SES, the lower the numbers). 

Dependent variables:
1)	Level of education, in 6 categories: (1)Less than high school, (2)High school graduate, (3)2-year college degree, (4)4-year college degree, (5)Graduate degree / Professional school, (6)Doctorate.
2)	Income, in 7 categories: (1) below$15,000; (2) $15,001–$30,000; (3) $30,001–$45,000; (4) $45,001–$75,000; (5) $75,001–$100,000; (6) $100,001–$150,000; (7) above$150,000

The correlations between their answer on the subjective SES scales and 1) level of education and 2) income will be assessed. We expect the correlations to be higher in the reversed scale than in the original scale condition. 

The full material of the project is attached.

q9.value: This is an online study. Participants will be randomly assigned to one or the other of the experimental condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants 
Participants will be american m-turkers. They will be paid 0,30$ in exchange of their participation in the present study. 

Outliers and Exclusions
A filter question is included in the questionnaire (“People vary in the amount they pay attention to these kinds of surveys. Some take them seriously and read each question, whereas others go very quickly and barely read the questions at all. If you have read this question carefully, please do not mark the scale below, and write the word "yes" in the blank box below labeled other”). Participant who mark this scale, or those who do not report “yes” in the blank will be removed from the analyses.

Analyses
The answers on the SES scale will be reverse-coded in the “reversed” condition, to make the two conditions comparable. 
Hypothesis will be tested in a regression model including subj SES (mean centred), the condition (original vs. reversed), and their interaction. 
An interaction should indicate that subj SES is more strongly related to level of education and income in the “reversed” (1 at the top) condition, than in the “original” condition (1 at the bottom).

q13.value: The difference between the two correlations obtained in our previous research is small. Thus, G*power analysis were computed, assuming a small effect size of f²= 0.02216558 (following the guidelines of Perugini, Gallucci, & Costantini, 2018). A sample of N=357 participants is required to have 80% chances to detect an effect of this size, at a p level of p = .05, two tailed. We plan to oversample a little bit by recruiting N = 400 participants (see attached file).

question.value: 2 experimental conditions: Participants will be presented either the original subjective SES scale (the higher the SES, the higher the numbers) or the reversed one (the higher the SES, the lower the numbers).

1)	Level of education, in 6 categories: (1)Less than high school, (2)High school graduate, (3)2-year college degree, (4)4-year college degree, (5)Graduate degree / Professional school, (6)Doctorate.

2)	Income, in 7 categories: (1) below$15,000; (2) $15,001–$30,000; (3) $30,001–$45,000; (4) $45,001–$75,000; (5) $75,001–$100,000; (6) $100,001–$150,000; (7) above$150,000

It is worth noting that participants will also be asked to report their current occupation and that of their partner (if any). In further analyses, these occupations will be categorized by two blinded coders as being low (1), middle (2), or high (3) SES occupations resulting in two scores: “individual SES” (participant’s SES) and “family SES” (the highest SES of the two occupations).
The correlations between these two scores and subjective SES will then be examined. Once again, we expect these correlations to be higher in the reversed scale condition than in the original scale condition.

Hypothesis will be tested in a regression model including subj SES (mean centred), the condition (original vs. reversed), and their interaction. 
An interaction should indicate that subj SES is more strongly related to level of education and income in the “reversed” (1 at the top) condition, than in the “original” condition (1 at the bottom).

1)	Level of education, in 6 categories: (1)Less than high school, (2)High school graduate, (3)2-year college degree, (4)4-year college degree, (5)Graduate degree / Professional school, (6)Doctorate.
2)	Income, in 7 categories: (1) below$15,000; (2) $15,001–$30,000; (3) $30,001–$45,000; (4) $45,001–$75,000; (5) $75,001–$100,000; (6) $100,001–$150,000; (7) above$150,000

The correlations between their answer on the subjective SES scales and 1) level of education and 2) income will be assessed. We expect the correlations to be higher in the reversed scale than in the original scale condition. 

The full material of the project is attached.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants 
Participants will be american m-turkers. They will be paid 0,30$ in exchange of their participation in the present study. 

Outliers and Exclusions
A filter question is included in the questionnaire (“People vary in the amount they pay attention to these kinds of surveys. Some take them seriously and read each question, whereas others go very quickly and barely read the questions at all. If you have read this question carefully, please do not mark the scale below, and write the word "yes" in the blank box below labeled other”). Participant who mark this scale, or those who do not report “yes” in the blank will be removed from the analyses.

Analyses
The answers on the SES scale will be reverse-coded in the “reversed” condition, to make the two conditions comparable. 
Hypothesis will be tested in a regression model including subj SES (mean centred), the condition (original vs. reversed), and their interaction. 
An interaction should indicate that subj SES is more strongly related to level of education and income in the “reversed” (1 at the top) condition, than in the “original” condition (1 at the bottom).

It is worth noting that participants will also be asked to report their current occupation and that of their partner (if any). In further analyses, these occupations will be categorized by two blinded coders as being low (1), middle (2), or high (3) SES occupations resulting in two scores: “individual SES” (participant’s SES) and “family SES” (the highest SES of the two occupations).
The correlations between these two scores and subjective SES will then be examined. Once again, we expect these correlations to be higher in the reversed scale condition than in the original scale condition.

q3.value:
Our project will focus on social media use and posting habits. In particular, we will examine how those who post large amounts of content on social media engage in 'habitual' behavior based on evidence that they begin to 'ignore' reactions from others, regardless of valence, desired emotional reaction, and other categories. 

We earlier conducted an online survey about people’s beliefs about their own Facebook use, and participants all believed that they would be moderately influenced by others’ reactions to their posts, regardless of how often they typically posted. The present project collects actual Facebook data to assess whether this is correct or whether, as predicted by theories of habit, that more habitual Facebook posters become relatively insensitive to rewards/comments/likes. 

We plan to conduct a second set of studies using Twitter, and propose to analytically scrape posts from about 400 people. Our measures include post frequency (as a proxy for habit--including SRBAI in the Facebook study), reaction valence, and other variables to determine whether people develop online 'posting habits' and how these 'habits' might function. Further studies may examine this behavior on social media networks that are not Twitter or Facebook.

q4.value:
We will test whether posting on Social Media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) can be considered a "habit" by examining post reactions and self-reported nightly social support (Facebook only) as a form of reward. All studies continue for 7-days. We predict that the evaluative reactions received to earlier posts will interact with habit strength (assessed through past post frequency and, for the Facebook study, the self-reported behavioral automaticity scale [SRBAI]) to predict latency to make a subsequent post. Specifically, we predict that others’ reactions will matter less for people with stronger posting habits. In particular, we predict that "more habitual" posters will:

A. Post in subsequent days regardless of the valence of reactions (positive or negative) to previous posts. 
B. Post in subsequent days regardless of the number of reactions received to previous posts. 
C. (Facebook Only) Post in subsequent days regardless of their perceived social support in previous days. Furthermore, for habitual posters, perceived social support should be less influenced by others’ reactions.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: There is no manipulation in this study, but no participant will be aware of the study hypotheses and those posting on Twitter will not be aware that their data are being included in the study.

question.value:
Participants will be monitored for 7 days in a week, in order to observe "live" the numbers of reactions occurring on their posts. This was done on Facebook by creating an “observer” profile, which was monitored by Research Assistants. This profile became “friends” with participants, allowing researchers to view their public Facebook posting activity.

On Facebook, we measure habit strength of social media site use via an intake survey, and email them to receive nightly updates of their feelings of social support. At the end of the week, we collect data on the time between their posts and the number of likes for prior posts (single post, 5-post, likes in last 24 hours, etc.). All data preserve anonymity by using participant identification numbers to de-identify the data and protect subject privacy.

On Twitter, participants are not aware their data are being observed, but collection has been done through Twitter’s official API. In this study, no data are collected via survey. Habit strength is assessed only using previous posting behavior. Valence of replies will be measured through text analysis of sentiment.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Facebook study data for self-reports of posting have already been collected and analyzed. The observational data have only been partially collected. An initial pilot of the observational study was pre-registered at Aspredicted (under Facebook_study in the OSF folder). This is a pre-registration before data collection and analysis of the Twitter data.

question.value: The twitter data is being collected via a scraping program that uses Twitter’s official API to live-monitor users on the site, collecting the numbers of reactions that occur between each tweet on the previous 20 tweets.

q13.value:
Facebook sample size:

Using Rsim to analyze 1000 randomly generated (via monte-carlo simulations) samples based on a simulated dataset and multilevel model similar to our predicted model and pretest data, we examined subject Ns ranging from 50-100 and total post Ns from ~500-1200 [estimated based on pre-test data]. 

Given expected effect sizes that are small-medium (.15-.30), we settled on an N = 60 subject count, as this would give us roughly 900-1000 posts to analyze. 
Power estimates for the N = 60, 900 post sample was 84.20% (95% CI: 81.79-86.41)

Twitter Sample Size:

Using Rsim to analyze 1000 randomly generated (via monte-carlo simulations) samples based on a simulated dataset and multilevel model similar to our predicted model and pretest data, we examined potential subject Ns ranging from 100-500 and total post Ns from ~10,000-15,000  [estimated based on pre-test data]. 

Given expected effect sizes that are small-medium (.15-.30), we settled on an N = 400 subject count, as this would give us roughly 12,000-15,000 posts to analyze.

Power Estimates for the N= 400, 12,000 post sample was 96.70% (95%CI: 95.40-97.72)

question.value: Not Applicable

Habit Strength (SRHI, Self-Reported Weekly Posts, Avg posts per day over the past month), Time difference between posts (Minutes, Hours), Quantity of Reactions (likes, shares), Positivity of reactions (ratio of positive replies to negative replies, as shown by a sentiment analysis tool for Twitter, and as coded by our team of RAs for Facebook).

An HLM will predict the interaction between habit strength and number and positivity/negativity of reactions. In the Facebook sample, high and low habit will be distinguished by number of posts per day, and we plan to evaluate the appropriateness of using a continuous measure of habit strength or an exact cutoff, depending on the distribution in our sample (Facebook). Our Twitter sample will be analyzed similarly, though the model might differ based on the expected higher rate of posting on Twitter.

q20.value: We will log-transform the time difference variable (the DV) in both studies, given the likely high skew.

q21.value: We will be using the standard p < .05 for significance in our model.

q22.value: We will exclude people who do not post during the study period, or post less than twice during the week, as we need two data points to produce a time-difference variable.

q23.value: These will be excluded from the study.
